title: Lost Circulation Management
description: Lost circulation is more than a mud cost problem - in HPHT wells, losses can compromise your hydrostatic barrier and trigger well control events. Managing losses while maintaining well control is a critical skill.
objectives: Identify loss severity and formation type
Maintain well control during loss events
Recognize when to drill ahead vs treat losses

keyTopics.content: Seepage (<10 bbl/hr) - may be manageable with LCM. Partial losses (10-50 bbl/hr) - require treatment before continuing. Severe losses (50-100+ bbl/hr) - likely need specialized treatment. Total losses (no returns) - emergency requiring immediate action.

Induced fractures (exceeded fracture gradient). Natural fractures (intersected fractured zone). Vugs and caverns (carbonates). Unconsolidated/high permeability (rare in HPHT). The mechanism determines treatment.

Lost circulation means lost hydrostatic. If losses occur while pore pressure is high, you can simultaneously have losses AND a kick. This is the most dangerous well control scenario - you cannot simply weight up without making losses worse.

Fibrous (nut shells, fibers) for general sealing. Granular (calcium carbonate, graphite) for matrix permeability. Flake (mica, cellophane) for induced fractures. Sized combinations for natural fractures. Cement for severe cases.

For seepage: continuous LCM in active system. For partial: high-concentration LCM pill, squeeze if needed. For severe: specialized LCM, cement, or crosslinked systems. For total: stop drilling, evaluate, may need cement or specialized plugs.

In tight windows, you often can't reduce MW to stop losses without risking a kick. MPD with reduced BHP, continuous LCM, or drilling ahead with managed losses may be required. Each decision balances kick risk against formation damage.

risks: High ECD may exceed FG at shoe during circulation
Tight window at TD - cannot reduce MW to stop losses
Losses + kick scenario is realistic possibility
OBM makes some LCM options less effective

operationalPrinciples: Losses are a symptom - identify the cause
Losses AND kicks happen together - stay vigilant
Treatment must match the loss mechanism
Sometimes the best option is to drill ahead and set casing
